thread.title: Higher prices mean Three into O2 won’t go, warn regulators
thread.title_full: Higher prices mean Three into O2 won’t go, warn regulators

title: Higher prices mean Three into O2 won’t go, warn regulators
text:
Welcome to your preview of The Times Subscribe now Higher prices mean Three into O2 won’t go, warn regulators Three had originally agreed to buy O2 from Telefonica for £10.25 billion EPA Nic Fildes Technology & Communications Editor Published 1 minute ago 
Plans for a £10.25 billion tie-up between Three and O2 could come to nothing after Europe‘s antitrust commissioner said that mergers in the telecoms sector lead to higher prices for consumers. 
In a double blow by regulators, the competition watchdog in Britain said that the deal “threatens to affect significantly competition in the UK”. 
The merger of the two mobile companies would create the country’s largest wireless player with 32 million customers. 
Three, which is owned by Hong Kong’s Hutchison Whampoa, has agreed to buy O2 from Telefónica in Spain and is pursuing another merger in Italy via a tie-up Subscribe now 
To see the full article you need to subscribe Subscribe
